comment.body: I used mpc which is a frontend to mpd (music player daemon). The cool thing is that there are a ton of frontends to mpd (mobile, web, GUI, console)

I remember when I was 12 the bank promised I would get a plastic card with 14. But when I was 14 they didn't deliver without a reason. I remember just too well how pissed off I was. The rules in BitCoin are not changed that easily.

This looks like a good service from the user perspective. But it also looks like piracy. What I would really like was a way to pay for the content with Bitcoin, and be sure it reaches the author. Not many content creators published donation addresses, not even Cory Doctorow. I know there is a long way to go. Buying through the established channels can be horribly inconvenient. Most of the time I can't get DRM free eBooks nor pay with Bitcoin. But just downloading doesn't feel right neither.

Something other that comes to mind: [Fahrenheit 451](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fahrenheit_451_%28film%29) which was the inspiration for the new [http 451](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_451) code for censorship.

I have my GPG keys on OpenPGP enabled USB devices. For me that is the only way to keep it save. Options include: Yubikey NEO, NitroKey, Gnuk... Even Bitcoin hardware wallets offer limited support for GPG keys.

So you left the army?
@Musickillerwork: So you are in the cyber army now. Lucky you. When I served we were always outside doing dirty stuff.

When I was in the army, stress was not really a problem. The humiliations from the superiors were unpleasant, but we were all in the same boat. Sleep deprivation was an issue. It makes people more submissive.
We had no access to computers, and phones had no big screens nor internet access back then. So we read magazines and books.
One guy from my unit once received a packet with an inflatable doll, but I don't know if he actually used it.
For how long do you have to serve?
Does it have libreboot?

It looks very similar to an old IBM/Lenovo notebook that I had which had libreboot. It was from the time before the i3 i5 i7 family of processors.
I think the [purism](https://puri.sm) devices also use libreboot with current i5 / i7 processors
Do youngsters these days know about Hungarian notation in naming variables? Anybody remember what the "paul" prefix means?

Hungarian notation was mainly used in C as far as I know to codify the type into the variable name. A p prefix is still common in C++ for pointer variables. But back in the day, lots more were used: i for integer, d for double, f for float, b for bool, s for string...   
or good old "paul" for pointer to array of unsigned long
It is a good example of how NOT to design an API
